title: What are the MPs asking and answering?
text:
Extract and prepare a clean database of questions and answers asked in the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha sessions, India.
Perform NLP analysis like NER, topic modeling, keyword extraction, relevance of answers to questions, and time-series analysis.

title: **Roshan** Prizak
text:
def clean_tokenize_doc(doc, unwanted_lines):
    tokens = word_tokenize(doc)
    tokens = [re.sub(r'\d+', '', tt) for tt in tokens]
    tokens = [re.sub(r'(\d|\W)+', '', tt) for tt in tokens]
    tokens = [tt for tt in tokens if tt not in unwanted_lines]
    return tokens

si = 256

with open("members_html.txt", "r") as fp:
    soup = BeautifulSoup(fp, "html.parser")
    
members_html = soup.find_all("option")
members = []
member_codes = []
question_filenames = []
question_members = []
question_topics = []
for i in range(len(members_html)):
    if members_html[i]["value"]=='':
        continue
    member_codes.append(members_html[i]["value"])
    members.append(members_html[i].get_text().strip())
    
files = glob.glob(f'memberwise_html/*.txt', recursive = False)
for file in files:
    mc = file.split("/")[-1].split(".")[0]
    I = [x for x in range(len(member_codes)) if member_codes[x]==mc][0]
    with open(file, "r") as fp:
        soup = BeautifulSoup(fp, "html.parser")
        
    table = soup.find("tbody")
    for row in table.find_all("tr"):
        entries = row.find_all("td")
        question_number = ""
        question_status = "AS"
        question_date = ""
        question_ministry = ""
        questioner = ""
        question_topic = ""
        question_session = ""
        for j in range(len(entries)):
            entry = entries[j]
            if j==1:
                question_number = entry.get_text().strip()
            if j==2:
                if "unstarred" in entry.get_text().strip().lower():
                    question_status = "AU"
            if j==3:
                question_date = entry.get_text().strip()
            if j==4:
                question_ministry = entry.get_text().strip()
            if j==6:
                question_topic = entry.get_text().strip()
            if j==7:
                question_link = entry.find("a")["href"]
                numbers = re.findall(r'\d+', question_link)
                question_session = numbers[0]
        if question_session==str(si):
            question_filenames.append(question_status+question_number+".txt")
            question_members.append(members[I])
            question_topics.append(question_topic)
        
files = glob.glob(f'data/text_files/{si}/*.txt', recursive = False)
unwanted_lines = ["", "..", "*", "**", "***", "****", "*****", "******", "*******"]
unwanted_lines.extend([f"Page{i}_pdfplumber" for i in range(1,50)])
unwanted_lines.extend(['page_pdfplumber'])
raw_docs = []
raw_headers = []
raw_questions = []
raw_answers = []
docs = []
headers = []
questions = []
answers = []
questioners = []
topics = []
filenames = []
will_pattern = r"\b[wW]ill\b"
answer_pattern = r"\b[aA]\s*[nN]\s*[sS]\s*[wW]\s*[eE]\s*[rR]\b"
answer_pattern = r"\b[aA]\s*[nN]\s*[sS]\s*[wW]\s*[eE]\s*[rR]\b(?! to)"
for file in files:
    fn = file.split("/")[-1]
    try:
        I = [x for x in range(len(question_filenames)) if question_filenames[x]==fn]
        questioners.append([question_members[x] for x in I])
        topics.append(question_topics[I[0]])
    except:
        questioners.append(None)
        topics.append(None)
        
    with open(file, "r") as f:
        doc = " ".join([x.strip() for x in f.readlines() if x.strip() not in unwanted_lines])
        raw_docs.append(doc)
        will_match = re.search(will_pattern, doc)
        if will_match:
            index = will_match.start()
            header = doc[:index].strip()
            question = doc[index:].strip()
            answer_match = re.search(answer_pattern, question)
            if answer_match:
                index = answer_match.start()
                answer = question[index+len(answer_match.group()):].strip().lstrip(' ,')
                question = question[:index].strip()
            else:
                answer = ""
        else:
            header = ""
            question = ""
            answer = ""
        raw_headers.append(header)
        raw_questions.append(question)
        raw_answers.append(answer)

        docs.append(clean_tokenize_doc(doc.lower(), unwanted_lines))
        questions.append(clean_tokenize_doc(question.lower(), unwanted_lines))
        answers.append(clean_tokenize_doc(answer.lower(), unwanted_lines))
        headers.append(clean_tokenize_doc(header.lower(), unwanted_lines))
        filenames.append(file.split("/")[-1].split(".")[0])

title: **Roshan** Prizak
text:
Question-answer pairs
Next, you will need to determine how to measure the similarity or match between a given question and answer. One approach is to use a similarity metric such as cosine similarity, which measures the angle between the vector representations of two pieces of text. Another approach is to use a language model such as BERT to calculate the likelihood that a given answer follows logically from the corresponding question. There are several Python libraries that can be used for text similarity and language modeling, including spaCy and TensorFlow.
Once you have a way to measure the similarity between questions and answers, you can use this metric to quantify how well each answer matches the corresponding question. For example, you could calculate the cosine similarity or BERT score for each pair of question-answer pairs in your corpus and use this to rank them in terms of how closely they match. You could also use threshold values to categorize the answers as vague, precise, or somewhere in between.
To analyze the vagueness or preciseness of the answers, you can use additional NLP techniques such as part-of-speech tagging, named entity recognition, or sentiment analysis. These techniques can help you identify specific words or phrases that contribute to the precision or vagueness of the answers. You could also use topic modeling techniques to identify common themes or topics in the questions and answers, which can help you understand which types of questions are more likely to result in vague or precise answers.

def remove_stop_words(tokenized_text, stop_words):
    filtered_text = [w for w in tokenized_text if not w in stop_words]
    filtered_text = [w for w in filtered_text if len(w)>1]
    filtered_text = [w for w in filtered_text if w[0] not in ['/', '\\', '']]
    return filtered_text

# Stop words expanded list: use when internet is working well again
stopwords_list = requests.get("https://gist.githubusercontent.com/rg089/35e00abf8941d72d419224cfd5b5925d/raw/12d899b70156fd0041fa9778d657330b024b959c/stopwords.txt").content
stop_words = set(stopwords_list.decode().splitlines())

# Alternatively, stop words from nltk can be used
# stop_words = set(stopwords.words('english'))
# Attaching a few more custom stop words
extra_stop_words = {'shri', 'year', 'also', 'always', 'often', 'app', ',', '(', ')', '{', '}', '.', '!', '?', '--', '/b', '\'s', '\'\'', 'n\'t', 'based', 'href', 'url', 'http', 'https', 'i.e', '\\', '/', '\'re'}
all_stop_words = stop_words.union(extra_stop_words)

filtered_docs = [remove_stop_words(td, all_stop_words) for td in docs]
filtered_headers = [remove_stop_words(td, all_stop_words) for td in headers]
filtered_questions = [remove_stop_words(td, all_stop_words) for td in questions]
filtered_answers = [remove_stop_words(td, all_stop_words) for td in answers]

ps = PorterStemmer()
stemmized_docs = [[ps.stem(w) for w in fd] for fd in filtered_docs]
stemmized_headers = [[ps.stem(w) for w in fd] for fd in filtered_headers]
stemmized_questions = [[ps.stem(w) for w in fd] for fd in filtered_questions]
stemmized_answers = [[ps.stem(w) for w in fd] for fd in filtered_answers]

corpus = [" ".join(doc) for doc in stemmized_docs]
corpus_headers = [" ".join(doc) for doc in stemmized_headers]
corpus_questions = [" ".join(doc) for doc in stemmized_questions]
corpus_answers = [" ".join(doc) for doc in stemmized_answers]


# Later for LDA clustering, max_df=0.1 works well, it gets rid of common words and phrases used in questions.
cv = CountVectorizer(max_df=0.1, ngram_range=(1,1))
vectors = cv.fit_transform(corpus_answers)
avg = vectors.mean(axis=0)
avg = pd.DataFrame(avg, columns = cv.get_feature_names_out())
avg = avg.T
avg = avg.rename(columns={0: 'score'})
avg['word'] = avg.index
avg_m = avg.sort_values('score', ascending=False)

def sort_coo(coo_matrix):
    tuples = zip(coo_matrix.col, coo_matrix.data)
    return sorted(tuples, key=lambda x: (x[1], x[0]), reverse=True)

def extract_topn_from_vector(feature_names, sorted_items, topn=10):
    """get the feature names and tf-idf score of top n items"""
    
    #use only topn items from vector
    sorted_items = sorted_items[:topn]
    score_vals = []
    feature_vals = []
    
    # word index and corresponding tf-idf score
    for idx, score in sorted_items:
        
        #keep track of feature name and its corresponding score
        score_vals.append(round(score, 3))
        feature_vals.append(feature_names[idx])
    #create a tuples of feature,score
    #results = zip(feature_vals,score_vals)
    results= {}
    for idx in range(len(feature_vals)):
        results[feature_vals[idx]]=score_vals[idx]
    
    return results

i = 60
n_kw_questions = 10
n_kw_answers = 20
n_common = []
for i in range(len(corpus_questions)):
    print(i)
    # n_kw_answers = n_kw_questions*int(len(corpus_answers[i])/len(corpus_questions[i]))
    cv_questions = CountVectorizer(max_df=0.1, ngram_range=(1,1))
    tfidf_transformer_questions = TfidfTransformer(smooth_idf=True,use_idf=True)
    count_vectors_questions = cv_questions.fit_transform(corpus_questions)
    tfidf_transformer_questions.fit(count_vectors_questions)
    feature_names_questions = cv_questions.get_feature_names_out()

    cv_answers = CountVectorizer(max_df=0.1, ngram_range=(1,1))
    tfidf_transformer_answers = TfidfTransformer(smooth_idf=True,use_idf=True)
    count_vectors_answers = cv_answers.fit_transform(corpus_answers)
    tfidf_transformer_answers.fit(count_vectors_answers)
    feature_names_answers = cv_answers.get_feature_names_out()

    tf_idf_vector = tfidf_transformer_questions.transform(cv_questions.transform([corpus_questions[i]]))
    sorted_items = sort_coo(tf_idf_vector.tocoo())
    keywords_questions = extract_topn_from_vector(feature_names_questions, sorted_items, n_kw_questions)

    tf_idf_vector = tfidf_transformer_answers.transform(cv_answers.transform([corpus_answers[i]]))
    sorted_items = sort_coo(tf_idf_vector.tocoo())
    keywords_answers = extract_topn_from_vector(feature_names_answers, sorted_items, n_kw_answers)

    n_common.append(len(set(keywords_questions).intersection(keywords_answers)))
    if i==100:
        break

 'ASSISTANCE TO FOLK PERFORMERS OF MAHARASHTRA DURING COVID-19 PANDEMIC 3209  DR. VIKAS MAHATME: (a)  whether  Government  has  conducted  any  survey  to  determine  the  impact  of COVID-19 pandemic on folk artists; (b)   if so, the details thereof indicating Government as well as non-Governmental support given to the folk artists; (c)   whether Government is organizing cultural programs to promote folk dances and arts of Maharashtra; (d)   if so, the details thereof; and (e)  details of measures taken to provide assistance to folk artists in view of the pandemic? MINISTER OF CULTURE, TOURISM AND DEVELOPMENT OF NORTH EASTERN REGION (SHRI G. KISHAN REDDY) (a) to (d)  To  promote  folk  dances  and  arts  throughout  the  country  including Maharashtra,  the  Government  has  set  up  seven  Zonal  Cultural  Centres  (ZCCs). Maharashtra is the member State of South Central Zone Cultural Centre (SCZCC), Nagpur and West Zone Cultural Centre (WZCC), Udaipur. All the seven ZCCs organize cultural activities and programmes on regular basis all over India including Maharashtra. Folk artists of various art forms from different parts of the country including Maharashtra are engaged by all the ZCCs to participate in these programmes for which honorarium, TA/DA, boarding & lodging and local transportation is provided to these artists to enable them to earn their livelihood. (e)  The following measures have been taken to provide assistance to folk artists in view of the pandemic: \uf0b7  Eastern Zone Cultural Centre (EZCC), Kolkata has supported more than 12000 artists through online programmes and organized production oriented workshops for craftsmen at Shilpagram, Santiniketan to help them financially. \uf0b7  South  Central  Zone  Culture  Centre  (SCZCC),  Nagpur  organized  online programmes and provided financial support to the artists by paying remuneration to them to the tune of Rs. 2,13,46,786/- during 2020-21 and 2021-22. \uf0b7  South Zone Cultural Centre (SZCC), Thanjavur extended financial assistance to the tune of Rs. 8,93,85,000/- to the artists during the Pandemic. \uf0b7  North Zone Cultural Centre (NZCC), Patiala organized online programmes and provided financial support to the artists to the tune of Rs. 2,59,08,000/- during 2020-21 and 2021-22 (upto 31.12.2021). \uf0b7  North Eastern Zone Cultural Centre (NEZCC), Dimapur organized virtual cultural programmes during COVID-19 Pandemic thereby benefitting 1725 artists during 2020- 21 and 5750  artists (till date) during 2021-22. \uf0b7  ZCCs have organized online programmes of the artists and broadcasting the same on various social media platforms like facebook and YouTube. The artists have been paid remuneration for their online performances. ANNEXURE Annexure referred to in reply to part (e) of Rajya Sabha Unstarred Question No. 3209 for 31.03.2022 STEPS TAKEN TO HELP THE ARTISTS DURING COVID PANDEMIC \uf0b7  In view of the prevailing conditions, the Ministry of Culture issued guidelines in October, 2020 to help artists/organizations who have already been sanctioned grant under various scheme components of ‘Kala Sanskriti Vikas Yojana (KSVY)’ to conduct events on virtual mode. This',

ANSWER THE MINISTER OF FINANCE (SMT.  'GOVERNMENT OF INDIA MINISTRY OF EDUCATION DEPARTMENT OF SCHOOL EDUCATION & LITERACY RAJYA SABHA STARRED QUESTION NO. 160 TO BE ANSWERED ON 16.03.2022 Subjects under skill development courses *160. Lt. Gen. (Dr.) D. P. Vats (Retd.): (a) to (f): A Statement is laid on the table of the House. STATEMENT REFERRED TO  IN REPLY  TO  PARTS  (a)  to (f) OF THE RAJYA SABHA  STARRED  QUESTION  NO.  160  FOR  REPLY  ON  16.03.2022  ASKED  BY LT.GEN.  (DR.)  D.  P.  VATS  (RETD.)  REGARDING  SUBJECTS  UNDER  SKILL DEVELOPMENT COURSES (a) & (b) :  The Department of School Education and Literacy is implementing the scheme  of  Vocationalisation  of  School  Education  under  the  Centrally  Sponsored Scheme - Samagra Shiksha. The scheme aims at integrating Vocational Education with general academic education in all Secondary/Senior Secondary schools; enhancing the employability and entrepreneurial abilities of the students, providing exposure to work environment; and generating awareness amongst students about various career options so as to enable them to make a choice in accordance with their aptitude, competence and aspirations.  The scheme covers Government and Government aided schools. Under  Vocationalisation  of  School  Education,  NSQF  compliant  vocational courses,  based  on  the  Job  roles  which  have  been  approved  by  National  Skill Qualification Committee (NSQC) under National Council of Vocational Education and Training (NCVET), are offered to the students from Class IX to XII in the schools covered under the scheme along with other academic subjects. There is a provision for arranging hands on training, field visits, on the job training for students in industrial set up and guest lecturers from industry. The State Boards conduct competency based assessment of skills of the students in collaboration with the concerned Sector Skill Council (SSC). Employability Skill module has been made a mandatory part of the vocational  Courses.  It  consists  of  Communication  Skills,  Self-Management  Skills, Information and Communication Technology Skills, Entrepreneurship Skills and Green Skills. Under the Scheme, 62 Vocational courses/Job Roles across 20 sectors are being offered in schools at present. The list of courses may be seen at Annexure - I. 14435 schools have been approved under the scheme out of which the scheme has so far been implemented in 11,710 schools with the reported total enrolment of 15,63,319 students. State-wise number of schools approved and functional along with enrolment may be seen at Annexure–II. (c) to (f):   ‘Education’ is in the Concurrent List of the Constitution and majority of the schools are under the jurisdiction of the respective State Governments and UT Administration.  Hence,  the  recruitment,  service  conditions  and  deployment  of teachers/trainers are primarily within the domain of respective State Governments and UT Administrations. However, the scheme has provision inter-alia for financial assistance to States/UTs for setting up of vocational labs, tools and equipment and engaging vocational teachers/trainers. 21271 trainers are engaged in 11710 schools implementing Vocational Education and tools and equipment have been procured in 9547 schools. \x0cPage3_pdfplumber Annexure – I STATEMENT REFERRED TO IN REPLY TO PARTS (a) and (b) OF THE RAJYA SABHA  STARRED  QUESTION  NO.  160  FOR  REPLY  ON  16.03.2022  ASKED  BY LT.GEN.  (DR.)  D.  P.  VATS  (RETD.)  REGARDING  SUBJECTS  UNDER  SKILL DEVELOPMENT COURSES List of Vocational Courses/Job Roles across *',

['Will the Minister of Finance be pleased to state: (a) whether Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has received complaints against senior officers of corporate houses for not disclosing purchase of shares worth crores under  the  Securities  and  Exchange  Board  of  India  (Prohibition  of  Insider  Trading) Regulations, 2021; (b) if so, the details of shares purchased by these officers of their company but not intimated to SEBI during the last five years, as per complaints; and (c) what  enforcement  action  SEBI  is  contemplating  against  corporate  houses/individuals under the SEBI Act, 1992 with the details and value of undisclosed shares purchased without intimating SEBI/NSE/BSE, company-wise?',
 'Will the Minister of COMMERCE & INDUSTRY be pleased to state: (a) whether  Government  intends  to  bring  any  scheme  to  help  the  traditional  coffee/tea growers and farmers to create additional revenue streams to make the growing process more sustainable and profitable; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) the  details  of  financial  and  technical  assistance  proposed  to  be  extended  to  coffee growers for inter-cropping of pepper and cardamom, besides options such as planting exotic fruit bearing trees, dairy farming, beekeeping, etc.; and (d) if so, the details of States and districts where the focus is being paid and the amount spent so far?',
 'Will the Minister of HOME AFFAIRS be pleased to state: (a)  how  many  rape  cases  are  registered  in  the  country  every  year  and whether the number is going up or down; (b) how many women are raped every day in the country; (c) whether 94 percent of the perpetrators are known to the victims; (d) the reasons why conviction rate has gone down in last three years; (e)  whether  Government  intends  to  make  the  law  more  stringent  and compel police to take more proactive and immediate action; (f) whether there is any plan to punish offenders in a shorter period of time; and (g)  whether  chemical  castration  of  proven  serial  rapists  has  been considered?',

 'will enable them to avail benefits under these schemes even if they are not able to stage programs in physical format as before and will ensure continued financial assistance to tide over the present crisis. \uf0b7  All efforts have been made to release the funds to already approved grantees under various financial schemes of the Ministry of Culture. The funds released during the first quarter of F.Y. 2020-21 was much more than that released during 1st quarter of FY 2019-2020. Similar efforts are being made in this financial year also. \uf0b7  In  view  of  COVID-19,  under  the  scheme  of  Repertory  Grant,  exemption  has  been granted to organizations from mandatory inspection for release of yearly grant. \uf0b7  All help has been extended to the grantees for completing various procedural formalities like compliance of mandatory EAT Module.  In respect of the scheme component of Cultural Function & Production Grant (CFPG), one-time exemption has been granted to the organizations from filing the expenditure in EAT module for release of 1st instalment to the grantees of 43rd and previous meetings of CFPGS. \uf0b7  In view of COVID-19, under the Scheme of Scholarship & Fellowship for Promotion of Art & Culture, selection of Senior Fellows for the Batch Year 2019-20 & mid-term and final evaluation of 06 monthly reports of earlier batches (upto Batch Year 2017-18) in respect of both Junior/Senior Fellows has been held through virtual mode in view of the large number of members of the Expert Committee. \uf0b7  Under the scheme of ‘Artists Pension’, one time exemption has been granted regarding submission of the mandatory annual income certificate by the pensioners. \uf0b7  All  the  ZCCs  have  encouraged  the  folk  artists/artisans  to  get  registered  with  their member States in order to avail the schemes announced by the States. \uf0b7  South Zone Cultural Centre (SZCC), Thanjavur in association with a Chennai based NGO Samarpana organized an online fund raising programme ”Notes of Nector-100 for 1000” participated by eminent artists from North and South. This fund raiser initiative has enabled 1200 families of folk artists to get financial assistance, groceries etc. during COVID-19 Pandemic. \uf0b7  All  the  ZCCs  took  care  of  artistes  admitted  to  hospitals/nursing  homes  and  held consultations with doctors to ensure the best treatment for them. Vaccination Camps in collaboration with a multispecialty hospital in Kolkata was arranged by EZCC through CSR fund for their artistes. Emergency lifesaving medicines/injections required by some of the artists admitted in the hospital were arranged by ZCCs through Health Department of the State Governments. \uf0b7  Efforts have been made to engage artists during Commemoration events enabling them to avail financial benefits out of the grants released by the Ministry.',

 'Will the Minister of HOUSING AND URBAN AFFAIRS be pleased to state: (a)  the details of Swachh Survekshan under the SBM (U) scheme, year-wise and city wise; (b)  the details of financial assistance given by the Central Government to the States during the last five years to improve cleanliness; and (c)  the details of Central assistance of funds towards the implementation of Swachh Bharat Mission Urban (SBM–U), year-wise, State-wise and city-wise? (a)  The Swachh Survekshan (SS) is an innovative survey that is conducted by the Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs (MoHUA) under the Swachh Bharat Mission – Urban, to rank cities across  various  sanitation  and  cleanliness  parameters.  The  survey  has  put  people  first  by successfully creating a spirit of healthy competition between states while they move towards achieving  the  ‘Swachhata’  goal.  Year-wise  and  city-wise  details  of  Swachh  Survekshan conducted till date is as Annexure – I. (b) & (c)   Central assistance under Swachh Bharat Mission – Urban is being released to States/UTs only. States further transfer the funds to Cities/ULBs. State and year-wise details of Central assistance of funds released for implementation of Swachh Bharat Mission-Urban is at Annexure – II. Annexure - I referred in reply to Rajya Sabha Unstarred Question no. 3590 for',

 'Will the Minister of AGRICULTURE AND FARMERS WELFARE be pleased to state: (a)      whether Government organises annual fair on horticulture and floriculture to apprise the farmers on the latest techniques and type of fruits and flowers for adoption to improve their income on regular basis; (b)       if not, the reasons there for; (c)      whether  Government  has any proposal  to  start  Government  owned  or  authorized nurseries for fruit and flower saplings in different parts of the country; and (d)  if so, by when such initiative would be taken and whether Government would encourage the States to treat the matter on priority basis? MINISTER OF AGRICULTURE AND FARMERS WELFARE (SHRI NARENDRA SINGH TOMAR) (a & b):    Annual fair on horticulture and floriculture are organized by State Governments’ horticulture Departments to apprise the farmers on the latest techniques and type of fruits and flowers for adoption to improve their income on regular basis. Assistance is also provided under Mission for Integrated Development of Horticulture (MIDH), a Centrally Sponsored Scheme, for such activities. (c & d):    The assistance is provided under MIDH for establishment of nurseries in Public and Private sectors for production of fruit and flower saplings in the country.  The details of Government norms and pattern of assistance is attached in Annexure-I. Annexure-I',

 'Will the Minister of HOUSING AND URBAN AFFAIRS be pleased to state:- (a)  whether Government proposes to integrate details of ID cards, Certificate of Vending (CoV) and any other documents into smart cards to prevent possibility of tampering associated with paper- based documents; (b)   if so, the details thereof and, if not, the reasons therefor; (c)  whether Government has taken steps to improve inclusivity of surveys under Street Vendors Act, 2014, given that many street vendors and hawkers are left out of surveys carried out due to lack of documents or not registered due to lack of awareness about survey; and (d)  if so, the details thereof and, if not, the reasons therefor? However, Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs has advised the States/ UTs to consider issuing Smart ID cards & Smart CoVs to check tampering, creation of digital database and facilitate easy access of data for various purposes. Samples of Smart ID/CoV have been circulated for guidance of States/UTs. (c) & (d):  The Street Vendors Act provides for survey to identify street vendors at least once in every five years. Where, in the intervening period between two surveys, any person seeks to vend, the Town Vending Committee may grant a CoV to such person, subject to the Scheme, the plan for street vending and the holding capacity of the vending zones. Further,  PM  Street  Vendors  AtmaNirbhar  Nidhi  (PM  SVANidhi)  scheme  being implementedby Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs since June 2020 enables those street vendors, who have been left out of the Urban Local Body (ULB)- led identification survey, to apply for the Letter of Recommendation (LoR). ULBs have been instructed to issue CoV within a month of issuance of LoR. So far, 29.4 lakh vendors have been issued LoR, who were left out of the survey conducted by ULBs.',

 'Will the Minister of HOUSING AND URBAN AFFAIRS be pleased to state: (a)  whether Government has launched the Swachhata Start Up Challenge under Swachh Bharat Mission – Urban 2.0; (b)  if so, the details thereof and the aims and objective behind the move alongwith financial allocation for this purpose; (c)  whether Government has taken steps to involve more and more startups in achieving the vision of garbage free cities under Swachh Bharat Mission – Urban 2.0 and, if so, the details thereof and the outcome thereof; and (d)   the other steps taken by Government to involve innovative startups to come forward and drive catalytic transformation in the sanitation and waste management sector? (a) & (b):  Government has launched ‘Swachhata Startup Challenge’  on January 27, 2022 in collaboration with Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) to promote an enabling environment for development startups and entrepreneurs in the waste management sector. Applications  received  from  startups  working  in  the  domain  of  four  thematic  areas  have been identified  viz.  (i)  Social  Inclusion  (ii)  Zero  Dump  (iii)  Plastic  Waste  Management  and  (iv) Transparency, will be evaluated for the quality of solutions offered. The scheme provides for the ten best solutions from the startups to be selected and each of them to get financial support of ₹25 Lakh per selected project and one year dedicated incubation support. (c) & (d): In addition to the “Swachhata Startup Challenge”, Government has also launched the “Swachh Technology Challenge” on December 6, 2021. …2/- -2- As per the “Swachh Technology Challenge” guidelines, all Urban Local Bodies (ULBs) conducted the challenge and submitted two best solutions to States after which States evaluated the entries to identify maximum three best entries. The ULBs across the country have to provide implementation support to the wining solutions startups other than award money and State/City level felicitation. Further, provisions have been made under Swachh Bharat Mission - Urban 2.0 Guidelines to encourage adoption of locally innovated, cost-effective technology solutions and business models in sanitation and solid waste management by startups, through investment in Research & Design (R&D)  and  facilitation  in  Government-e-Market  (GeM)  portal,  in  order  to  take  forward  the Government’s vision of an “Aatma Nirbhar Bharat” and “Make in India”.',

 'will consider the option of reducing its stake to below 50% in the IDBI Bank. In pursuance of this announcement, LIC had acquired 51% controlling stake in IDBI Bank Ltd. with the approval of IRDAI and RBI. Subsequently, in the budget speech  for  2021-22,  strategic  disinvestment  of  GoI’s  equity  in  IDBI  Bank  was announced and as per the CCEA’s decision of May 2021, it has been decided to have strategic disinvestment of GoI and LIC shareholding in IDBI Bank along with transfer of management control. It is expected that the strategic buyer will infuse funds, new technology and best management practices for optimal development of business potential and growth of IDBI Bank Ltd. and shall generate more business without  dependence  on  LIC  and  GoI  for  capital.  Unlocking  of  resources  by  the strategic disinvestment of GoI’s equity in IDBI Bank Ltd. would be used to finance the social sector/developmental programs of the Government benefitting the citizens. 2',

 'Will the Minister of ELECTRONICS AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGYbe pleased to state: (a) the State-wise details of rural-urban digital literacy levels in the country; (b) the gender-wise details of digital literal literacy levels in the country; (c) whether it is a fact that the country continues to have very low levels of overall rural digital literacy; and (d) the details of the schemes launched by Government to improve the digital literacy rate, especially in rural India, in the last three years? (a): Digital Literacy is becoming an important requirement during COVID and post COVID reality  as  digitisation  of  citizens,  businesses  and  Government  is  accelerating.  The  National Statistical  Office  (NSO)  under  the  Ministry  of  Statistics  and  Programme  Implementation conducted a survey on Household Social Consumption: Education as part of the 75th round of National Sample Survey (NSS) from July 2017 to June 2018. As per the report, among people in the age group of 15-59 years, 12.6% in rural and 38% in urban areas are able to operate a computer and around 17% in rural and 44.7% in urban populations are able to use the internet. The state-wise details of rural-urban digital literacy levels is not available in the said report. (b): and (c): As per the 75th round of National Sample Survey (NSS) report, the gender-wise details of digital literacy levels in the age groups mentioned below in rural and urban India are as under: (d): In order to improve the digital literacy rate especially in rural India, the Government of India has approved a scheme titled “Pradhan Mantri Gramin Digital Saksharta Abhiyan (PMGDISHA)” \x0cPage2_pdfplumber in 2017 to usher in digital literacy in rural India by covering 6 crore rural households (one person per household). As on 7th February, 2022,  around 5.56 crore candidates have been enrolled and 4.69 crore candidates have been trained, out of which 3.48 crore candidates have been certified under the PMGDISHA Scheme. Out of these certified candidates, more than 1.92 crore candidates are female  and  around  1.55  crore  candidates  are  male.  The  state/UT-wise  achievements  of PMGDISHA scheme are at Annexure.  'Will the Minister of HEALTH AND FAMILY WELFARE be pleased to state: (a) the major projects and special programmes that the Union Government is undertaking in the health sector in West Bengal; (b) the project costs of the major ones in West Bengal and their time and cost schedules, as well as their benefits; and (c) whether any pockets in the State require special programmes for chronic local diseases and the details of the same? (a) to (c) “Public Health and Hospitals” is a State subject and the primary responsibility of strengthening public healthcare system including up gradation and strengthening of existing health facilities lies with the respective State/ UT. Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW), under NHM provides technical and financial support to the States/UTs including West Bengal to strengthen their public healthcare system. Proposal from State Government of West Bengal is received in the form of Programme Implementation Plans (PIPs) and after appraisal approvals are given in the form of Record of Proceedings (RoPs) as per resource envelope of the State. Under NHM support for an amount of Rs 3301.02 Crore has been approved in FY 2021-22 to the State of West Bengal. The details of PIPs and RoPs for the past years i.r.o. West Bengal are available at website of National Health Mission www.nhm.gov.in at the Uniform Resource Locator (URL) as under: https://nhm.gov.in/index4.php?lang=1&level=0&linkid=62&lid=75 Under Ayushman Bharat, the existing Sub-health Centres (SHCs) and Primary Health Centres (PHCs) are upgraded into Ayushman Bharat -  Health & Wellness Centres (AB-HWCs) to  deliver  twelve  packages  of  Comprehensive  Primary  Health  Care  (CPHC)  that  includes preventive, promotive, curative, palliative and rehabilitative services which is universal, free and \x0cPage2_pdfplumber close to the community. As on date, 6042 Health & Wellness Centres have been operationalized as on 10.03.2022 as reported by the State of West Bengalon the AB-HWC Portal. The  PM-Ayushman  Bharat  Health  Infrastructure  Mission  (PM-ABHIM)  is  the largest Health Infrastructure scheme in the Country which aims to address the critical gaps in health infrastructural, surveillance and health research – spanning both the urban and rural areas. The scheme has Centrally Sponsored Scheme Components along with some Central Sector Components. Under the CSS components, States/UTs have been supported to strengthen the States’ Health Infrastructure. Under the scheme, State of West Bengal is allocated an amount of Rs 2625.16 Crore for implementation period of 2021-22 to 2025-26. The support is provided for Construction  of  Building-less  Sub  Health  Centres,  operationalization  of  Urban  Health  & Wellness Centres, establishment of District Integrated Public Health laboratory, 100 bedded Critical Care Blocks and 50 bedded Critical Care Blocks during the scheme period. The Government of India is also implementing Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Yojana (PMSSY) which aims correcting regional imbalances in the availability of affordable tertiary healthcare services and to augment facilities for quality medical education in the country. The Scheme has two components viz. (i) Setting up of All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS)  and  (ii)  Upgradation  of  existing  Government  Medical  Colleges/  Institutions (GMCIs).  So far setting up of 22 new AIIMS and 75 projects of upgradation of GMCIs have been approved under the Scheme in various phases. Upgradation of GMCIs under PMSSY broadly involves construction of Super Speciality Block (SSB) and/or Trauma Centre / or other facilities and/or procurement of medical equipment. In so far as State of West Bengal is concerned, the details of the approved projects under PMSSY is placed at Annexure-I. National  Programme  on  Antimicrobial  Resistance  Containment  under  umbrella scheme  “Establishment  and  strengthening  of  National  Centre  for  Disease  Control  (NCDC) branches  and  Health  Initiatives,  Inter-sectoral  coordination  for  preparation  and  control  of zoonotic Diseases and other neglected tropical diseases, surveillance of Viral Hepatitis, Anti Microbial Resistance (AMR)”, was initiated during the 12th five-year plan (2012-17) and is coordinated  by  NCDC,  MoHFW.  Under  the  programme  State  medical  college  labs  are strengthened in a phased manner for AMR surveillance and containment activities. In the year 2020-21,  School  of  Tropical  Medicine,  Kolkata,  West  Bengal  was  included  under  the programme. The lab is supported with funds for recruiting manpower, purchase of equipment and consumable. Fund of Rs 19,80,202/- has been released as on date. The network labs are to carry out various activities for AMR containment including submission of AMR surveillance data for pathogens of public health importance, antimicrobial  use surveillance and develop antibiograms  for  guiding  the  development  of  local  antibiotic  policy.  The  programme encompasses  the  benefits  which  includes  strengthening  of  the  Microbiology  Department, Burdwan Medical College to carry out surveillance of viral hepatitis and estimate the burden of viral hepatitis in the State of West Bengal.  'Will the Minister of HOUSING AND URBAN AFFAIRS be pleased to state: (a) the details of funds sanctioned, released and utilized under each of the five components of  the  PMAY-(U)  i.e  In-Situ  Rehabilitation  (ISR),  Affordable  Housing  Partnership (AHP),  Beneficiary-led  Individual  House  Construction/Enhancement  (BLC),  Credit Linked Subsidy (CLS) and Affordable Rental Housing Complexes (ARHCs), year-wise, State-wise and city-wise for the last five years; and (b) the  details  of  demand  assessed,  houses  sanctioned,  grounded  for  construction, completed, year-wise and State-wise and city-wise under all five PMAY-(U) verticals i.e., ISR, AHP, BLC, CLS, ARHCs? (a) to (b).Land’ and ‘Colonization’ are State subjects. The respective States/Union Territories (UTs) addresses the housing needs of its population. The Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs, under the vision of ‘Housing for All’, is supplementing the efforts of States/ UTs by providing  Central  Assistance  under  Pradhan  Mantri  Awas  Yojana-Urban  (PMAY-U),  for construction of houses for all eligible families/ beneficiaries since 25.06.2015 in the urban areas of the country. Eligible beneficiaries can avail the benefit of PMAY-U through four verticals, i.e. Beneficiary-led Construction or enhancement (BLC); Affordable Housing in Partnership (AHP);‘In-Situ’ Slum Redevelopment (ISSR) and Credit Linked Subsidy Scheme (CLSS). The Affordable Rental Housing Complexes (ARHCs) launched by Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs (MoHUA) as a sub-scheme of PMAY-U to provide dignified living to urban migrants/ poor near their workplace. This scheme is being implemented through two models: ...2/- -2- Model-1: Utilizing existing Government funded vacant houses constructed under Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JnNURM) and Rajiv Awas Yojana (RAY) to convert into ARHCs through Public Private Partnership (PPP) or by Public Agencies; and Model-2: Construction, Operation & Maintenance of ARHCs by Public/ Private Entities on their own available vacant land. Further, in Model -1 of ARHC, out of total 83,534 existing government funded vacant houses constructed under JnNURM and RAY in different States/ UTs, 5,478 houses  have  been  converted  into  ARHCs  and  7,483  houses  are  under  process  of  getting converted as ARHCs across the country. Under Model-2, Expression of Interest (EoI) has issued three times so far to invite proposals from Public/ Private Entities to construct ARHCs on their own available vacant land. In response, proposals for construction of 78,885 new ARHC units have been sanctioned. So far Technology Innovation Grant (TIG) of ₹ 175 crore has been approved of which ₹ 83.26 crore has been released.  State/ UT-wise details of houses converted/approved under ARHC is at Annexure-I. To address their housing needs, the participating States/ UTs have undertaken demand survey and reported a demand of 112.24 lakh houses in urban area of the Country, State/  UT-wise  details  of  which  are  at  Annexure-II.  Against  this  demand,  115.48  lakh houseshave been sanctioned as on 21.03.2022; of which 95.13 lakh houses have been grounded for  constructionand  56.33  lakh  houses  have  been  completed.The  houses  sanctioned  under PMAY-U involves Central Assistance of ₹ 1,89,302 crore of this, ₹ 1,12,265 crore has been released and ₹ 1.02 lakh crore has been utilized. State/ UT-wise details of houses sanctioned, grounded for construction and completed along with Central Assistance approved, released and utilized under PMAY-U are at Annexure-III. Further,under CLSS, interest subsidy is provided to  eligible  beneficiaries  through  Central  Nodal  Agencies  for  acquisition  of  houses  by purchase/re-purchase or construction. State/UT-wise details of interest subsidy disbursed under CLSS are at Annexure-IV.  City-wise and component-wise details for the above in last five years is also available at URL http://pmay-urban.gov.in/city-additional-details-1.pdf. Annexure I referred in reply to RSUSQ No. 3586 for',

 'will grow to meet their social and development needs. Developed countries have to take the lead in mitigation and provide climate finance, low-cost climate technologies and capacity building.  India is on track to meet its Nationally Determined Contributions, which are compatible with a well-below-2°C scenario. Further, the Hon’ble Prime Minister of India at the recent 26thsession of the Conference of Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP 26) presented India’s vision to achieve carbon neutrality by 2070. India, for its part, abides by commitments to the UNFCCC in letter and spirit. India with more than 17% of the global population has contributed only about 4% of the global cumulative greenhouse gas emissions between 1850 and 2019. Even though we are not part of the problem, India is committed to being part of the solution and has done far more than its fair  share.  India  has  progressively  continued  decoupling  of  economic  growth  from greenhouse gas emissions. In key sectors of the economy, the mitigation efforts have been undertaken with a vision of low-carbon, sustainable development. India’s commitment to emission intensity reduction of the economy is an economy- wide target that encompasses various sectors including transport and energy sectors. The Government stands committed to combating climate change through its several programs and schemes. The  National  Action  Plan  on  Climate  Change  (NAPCC)  comprises  missions  in specific areas of solar energy, energy efficiency, water, sustainable agriculture, Himalayan ecosystem,  sustainable  habitat,  green  India,  and  strategic  knowledge  for  climate change.Thirty-three States /Union Territories (UTs) have prepared their State Action Plan on Climate Change (SAPCC) in line with NAPCC taking into account the State-specific issues relating to climate change. The National Hydrogen Mission aims to cut down carbon emissions and increase the use of renewable sources of energy while aligning India’s efforts with global best practices in technology, policy, and regulation. The Government has taken various initiatives to accelerate the decarbonisation of transport  and  adoption  of  electric  mobility  in  the  country.  The  Faster  Adoption  and Manufacturing of Electric Vehicles scheme supports the electric vehicle market development and  its  manufacturing  eco-system  to  achieve  self-sustenance.Government  has  been implementing  the  Ethanol  Blended  Petrol  (EBP)  Programme,  wherein  Oil  Marketing Companies (OMCs) sell petrol blended with ethanol up to 10%. Encouraged by the past 7 years performance, the Government decided to advance the target of 20% ethanol blending in petrol  from  2030  to  2025.  SATAT  (Sustainable  Alternative  Towards  Affordable Transportation) initiative for boosting production and availability of Compressed Bio Gas (CBG) as an alternative and affordable clean fuel for transportation sector was launched by the Government of India on 1.10.2018. The scheme envisages setting up of 5000 CBG plants by  FY 2023-24. Indian Railways has taken a number of initiatives including setting up dedicated freight corridors, railway electrification, improving energy efficiency in traction, and increasing share of renewable energy. Indian Railways has set a target of making itself ‘net zero’ by 2030.',

 'Will the Minister of CULTURE be pleased to state: (a)  whether it is a fact that the Government has started cultural mapping of villages in the country; cultures, traditions, art forms, etc., of identified villages? MINISTER OF CULTURE, TOURISM AND DEVELOPMENT OF NORTH EASTERN REGION (SHRI G. KISHAN REDDY) (a) & (b)  Yes, Sir. Ministry of Culture, Government of India has undertaken the task of cultural mapping of the villages in the country.  Aims and objectives of such mapping are given as under : •  To culturally map the artists and art practices of diverse communities of India to  create  a  National  Data  Bank  of  artists,  crafts  people  &  art  and  craft practices. •  To create awareness about the strengths of cultural heritage and the interface between development, culture, and identity. •  To dovetail various welfare schemes of the Ministry of Culture for the artists. •  To create barcoded Unique Identification Codes (UID) for artists and crafts persons. •  To link tourism with culture by providing blueprints for developing Kala grams, art hubs, community resource centres, and cultural tourist hubs. (c)  The  villages  from  the  state  of  Andhra  Pradesh  which  have  been selected/identified for mapping are: •  Mogallu – West Godavari District. •  Budnathapalli – Vijaynagram Further, the villages selected from Andhra Pradesh for 360° video shoot are as follows: •  Malladhi •  Undavalli •  Nadakuduru •  Lambasing …2/- -2- •  Peruru •  Lamhi •  Budathanapalli •  Gangadevipalli •  Pandrangi •  Shankaram (d)  Database of the mission is based on the following constituents: i.  National register and Interactive database of artists and art practices from the villages of India ii.  National Directories of artists and art practices. iii.  Unique identification code for the artist. iv.  E-commerce platform v.  Single cultural service provider platform for all the welfare schemes of vi.  Government of India for artists and artisans of the country. vii.  Virtual museum of the villages showing their arts, crafts and culture. Indira  Gandhi  National  Centre  for  Arts  (IGNCA)  which  is  an  autonomous organization under the administrative control of Ministry of Culture has been designated as implementation agency for the National Mission on Cultural Mapping (NMCM).  The work under the mission involves coordinating the data collection through ground and field surveys conducted on the basis of detailed formats & questionnaires, mobile application, interactive web-portal and an Over-The-Top (OTT) platform to showcase ethnographic documentaries/cultural events/ festival/ meals etc. of villages. (e)  The strategy identified to protect and promote identified cultures, traditions, art forms, etc., of identified villages include the following steps: •  Creation  of  unique  Identification  Codes  (UID)  to  dovetail  various  welfare schemes of the Ministry of Culture with artists and crafts persons. •  Organisation  of  awareness  programs  describing  the  strengths  of  cultural heritage and the interface between development, culture, and identity. •  Development  of  Kala  grams,  art  hubs,  community  resource  centres,  and cultural tourist hubs. •  Creation of National Cultural Work Place (NCWP) to serve as a common interaction workplace for all stakeholders including artistes, institutions, NGOs, and Ministry of Culture so as to make e-learning interesting and facilitate clarity of concepts to the artistes. •  Setting up an e-commerce facility to provide various opportunities to artistes for direct  marketing,  cutting  out  the  middleman  and  empowering  traditional occupational communities to be an important goal of the National Cultural Web Portal.',

 'Will the Minister of HEALTH AND FAMILY WELFARE be pleased to state: (a) to (d): The National Health Mission (NHM) envisages achievement of universal access to equitable,  affordable  &  quality  health  care  services  that  are  accountable  and  responsive  to people’s needs. Public  Health  and  Hospitals  is  a  State  subject  and  the  primary  responsibility  of strengthening public healthcare system including up gradation and strengthening of existing health facilities lies with the respective State/ UT. However, under NHM, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) provides the technical and financial support to States/UTs based on the proposals received from States within their overall resource envelope. Under NHM, Common Review Missions (CRM) are conducted annually to assess and monitor  the  progress  and  implementation  status  under  the  scheme.  During  the  year  2019, MoHFW had conducted review on the status of various activities through 13th CRM in 16 States/ UTs including Gujarat. The key strategies and priority areas of CRM is to analyze challenges with  respect  to  strengthening  health  systems,  identify  trends  in  progress  of  key  indicators, evaluate the readiness of the state to undertake implementation of new initiatives, and review the \x0cPage2_pdfplumber progress and coordination mechanisms with various partners. The details of 13th CRM report are available at website of National Health Mission i.e. https://nhm.gov.in at the Uniform Resource Locator (URL) as under: https://nhm.gov.in/New_Updates_2018/Monitoring/CRM/13th/13th-CRM_Report.pdf Further, under NHM, the performance of various health programmes in all the States/UTs including Gujarat State is assessed through review meetings, video conferences & field visits of senior  officials,  promoting  performance  by  setting  up  benchmarks  for  service  delivery  & rewarding achievements etc and are also assessed through external surveys such as, National Family Health Survey (NFHS) and Sample Registration System (SRS). Further to strengthen the healthcare system in all the States/ UTs including Gujarat, Government of India has taken following new initiatives: \uf0b7  The recommendations of 15th Finance Commission (FC-XV) w.r.t Health Grants through Local Governments announced in Union Budget 2021-22, addresses the gaps in Primary Healthcare facilities throughout the country. Out of the total grants for health through Local Governments of Rs 70,051 crore, Rs 43,928 Crore has been allocated as tied grants for the 28 states through Rural Local Bodies (RLBs) and Rs. 26,123 Cr has been allocated as tied grants for Urban local bodies (ULBs).',

 'Will the Minister of TOURISM be pleased to state: (a)  whether Government agrees with the view that India needs a comprehensive disruptive strategy to tap the potential of the tourism and hospitality sector; (b)  if so, steps that are proposed to be taken by Government in this regard; and (c)  if not, the reasons therefor? (a) to (c):  Yes, Sir.  In order to create an enabling policy framework and strategic plan in partnership with Central, State and Local Governments and Industry Stakeholders to improve framework conditions for Tourism in the Country, support tourism industries, strengthen tourism support functions and develop various tourism subsectors, Ministry of Tourism has formulated a draft National Tourism Policy. The initiatives/steps proposed/being taken by the Government to tap the potential of the tourism and hospitality sector are given at Annexure. ANNEXURE STATEMENT  IN  REPLY  TO  PARTS  (a)  TO  (c)  OF  RAJYA  SABHA  UNSTARRED QUESTION  NO.3346  ANSWERED  ON  31.03.2022  REGARDING  DEVELOPMENT  OF TOURISM AND HOSPITALITY SECTOR 1.  The following initiatives have been proposed under the draft National Tourism Policy:- (i)  Setting up of the National Missions on:- (a)  Green Tourism for mainstreaming sustainability into Tourism sector. (b)    Digital Tourism to promote digitalization in tourism sector. (c)  Tourism  and  Hospitality  Sector  Skill  to  create  synergy  between  skill development framework and sectoral growth strategies. (d)   Destination  Management  Organizations  (DMOs)  to  develop  and implement a framework for DMOs. (e)  Tourism  MSMEs  to  create  jobs  and  entrepreneurial  opportunities  and contribution in the growth of tourism. (ii)  Further, it has been proposed to strengthen following strategic areas:- (a)  To introduce measures to make VISA, Immigration and Custom Processes more efficient and effective. (b)   To make India a welcoming, safe, clean and hygienic destination. (c)   To provide seamless connectivity and transport infrastructure. (d)   To develop and promote tourist destinations in a planned manner. (e)   To promote investment in tourism sector. (f)   To make a coherent marketing and promotion strategy. (g)   To  lay  down  a  robust  framework  for  Quality  Assurance  and Standardization. (h)  Research and Development Strategies to meet the needs of the industry and Government (i)   Governance, Institutional linkages and Stakeholders engagement. (j)   To prepare product specific broad roadmaps. 2.  Apart  from  the  above,  the  following  steps  are  being  taken  by  the  Government  for promotion and development in tourism and hospitality sector:- (i)  The Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, has relaxed the restriction for all foreign nationals intended to visit India for Tourism purposes subject to the COVID related guidelines of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. The e- Tourist Visa/Tourist Visa is fully  restored for  all individual foreign nationals intended to visit India for tourism purposes w.e.f. 15th November, 2021. Initially, the e- Tourist/Tourist Visa is being issued with the validity of 30 days. Ministry of Home Affairs has further relaxed and restored the long term tourist visa [e- tourist visa and regular (paper) tourist visa] as well with effect from 15.03.2022. \x0cPage3_pdfplumber Further, the Government of India has announced first 500,000 free visa to the international tourists. (ii)  Recognizing the fact that revival in the tourism sector will be largely spearheaded by Domestic tourism, the Ministry of Tourism launched the Dekho Apna Desh (DAD) initiative in January 2020 with the objective of creating awareness among the  citizens  about  the  rich  heritage  and  culture  of  the  country,  encouraging citizens  to  travel  widely  within  the  country  and  enhancing  tourist  footfalls leading to development of local economy and creation of jobs at the local level. This initiative is in line with the 15th August 2019 address of the Honorable Prime Minister asking every citizen to visit at least 15 destinations by the year 2022 to promote domestic tourism. (iii)  Under this initiative Ministry is organizing a series of webinars/events under the overall theme of DAD, showcasing the diverse culture, heritage, destinations and tourism products of the country. As on date 121 webinars covering different States/ Union Territories have been organized as part of the initiative. (iv)  To create mass awareness, the Ministry has   also launched an online DAD pledge and Quiz on the MyGov platform. The online pledge and Quiz are open to all for participation. (v)  DAD initiative is being promoted extensively on   social media accounts and website of the Ministry and by Domestic India Tourism offices.',

 'Will the Minister of HOUSING AND URBAN AFFAIRS be pleased to state: (a)   the  names  of  the  cities  covered  under  Atal  Mission  for  Rejuvenation  &  Urban Transformation 2.0 (AMRUT 2.0) across the country; (b)   the details of distribution of fund and the details of budgetary allocation for the AMRUT 2.0 projects across the country in comparison to AMRUT 1.0; and (c)   the reasons that the budgetary allocation proportion in AMRUT 2.0 has not increased in Tamil Nadu in comparison to other States and the details thereof? (a):  Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation 2.0 (AMRUT 2.0) is designed to provide universal coverage of water supply through functional taps to all households in all the statutory towns in the country and universal coverage of sewerage / septage management in 500 cities covered in first phase of the AMRUT scheme.  List of notified statutory cities /towns of the country  as  on  01.10.2021  can  be  accessed  on  the  Ministry’s  website  on  the  address: https://mohua.gov.in/cms/amrut.php . (b):  The total Central allocation for the AMRUT projects for the entire Mission period is ₹35,990 crore and total Central allocation for the AMRUT 2.0 projects for the Mission period is ₹66,750.  The State /Union Territory (UT) – wise distribution of Central outlay for projects under AMRUT and AMRUT 2.0 is given at ANNEXURE – I. …2/- -2- (c):  The Central allocation of ₹35,990 crore for AMRUT projects was distributed among States/ UTs using an equitable formula in which equal (50:50) weightage was given to the urban population (Census 2011) of each State/UT and the number of statutory towns in the State/UT. The Central allocation of ₹66,750 crore for AMRUT 2.0 projects have been distributed among the States/UTs using the equitable formula wherein weightage to urban population (Census 2011) and area of each State/ UT have been given in the ratio of 90:10. As per the earlier adopted formula, Tamil Nadu was allotted central assistance of ₹4,756 crore for AMRUT  and has been allotted ₹4,935  for AMRUT 2.0 under new formula. ANNEXURE – I REFERRED TO IN THE REPLY TO RAJYA SABHA UNSTARRED QUESTION No. 3583 DUE FOR',

 'Will the Minister of TRIBAL AFFAIRS be pleased to state: MINISTER OF STATE FOR TRIBAL AFFAIRS (SMT. RENUKA SINGH SARUTA) (a) Ministry of Tribal Affairs (MoTA) has taken various initiatives to facilitate marketing of tribal produce and the products made by the tribal people, which include the following: (i)  The  Ministry  provides  funds  to  States  and  Tribal  Co-Operative  Marketing  Development Federation of India (TRIFED) for organizing tribal festivals wherein the tribal artists and artisans showcase and sell their products.  The details of National Tribal festival (Adi-Mahotsav), State level Adi Mahotsav organized by TRIFED and funds given to different State Governments for organizing such festivals is given in Annexure 1. These festivals and exhibitions showcase their traditional skill in painting, art and craft, organic products and also demonstrate glimpses of rich cultural heritage through unique forms of folk dances, songs, cuisine,. Due to Covid, pandemic during 2020-21and 2021-22, States and TRIFED were advised to organize such festival(s) after following Covid protocol and avail the use of digital platforms. (ii) MoTA provides funds to TRIFED and State Governments for marketing of tribal products by empaneling tribal suppliers comprising of individual tribal artisans, tribal SHGs, Organisations/ Agencies/NGOs working with the tribals. (iii) TRIFED also organizes Tribal Artisan Mela (TAM) at District/Tehsil level as an exercise to reach tribals located in interior areas and source tribal art and craft directly from them. Through this initiative, Tribal Artisans are invited to an exhibition area where they display their artifacts. (iv) TRIFED is also engaged in direct purchase and sale of tribal products including artifacts through its network of Tribes India Showrooms, exhibitions, Aadi Mahotsav, online e-commerce portal etc. The amount utilized in the last five years for purchase of tribal products is at Annexure 2. (b) The list of minor forest produce for which minimum support price is provided under the scheme ‘Marketing  of  Minor  Forest  Produce  (MFP)  Through  Minimum  Support  Price  (MSP)  And Development of Value Chain For MFP’ is at Annexure 3. (c) The Ministry of Tribal Affairs in coordination with State Government always strives for livelihood driven sustainable tribal development. The approach  is aimed at developing or growing by using resources in a way that allows for them to renew or continue to exist for others and protecting the environment.   As part of this continuing endeavor, cabinet has approved Pradhan Mantri Janjatiya Vikas Mission for the XV Finance Commission cycle.   The Mission seeks to achieve livelihood driven tribal development in the next five years through formation of Vandhan groups who have been organized into Vandhan Kendras.  The MFP gathered by tribals will be processed in these kendras and marketed through  Van Dhan Producer Enterprises.  New haats bazaar and ware houses will be developed in next 5 years as part of “Atmanirbhar Bharat Abhyan”.  TRIFED would be the nodal agency for implementing the scheme. The products produced will be marketed through Tribe India Stores. An amount of Rs. 1612 cr has been earmarked under the Mission for next five years. In the budget, an amount of Rs. 499 cr. has been earmarked under the mission. Annexure 1 Annexure 1 referred to in Part (a) of the Reply to RSUQ No. 934 for 09.02.2022 National tribal festival/carnival organized by TRIFED since 2015 State level festivals organized during 2019-20 by TRIFED: State Festivals funded through TRI Scheme of Ministry during 2020-21 Annexure 2 Annexure 2 referred to in Part (a) of the Reply to RSUQ No. 934 for 09.02.2022 Purchase of tribal produce in the last five years (Rs. In lakhs) Annexure 3 Annexure 3 referred to in Part (b) of the reply to RSUQ No. 934 for',

 'Will the Minister of HOUSING AND URBAN AFFAIRS be pleased to state: (a) whether Delhi NCR faces maximum traffic jams during the monsoon months due to rains; (b) whether Delhi NCR roads are not designed to handle rain in access of 50 mm; (c) whether this is due to decades old drainage master plan this is currently operational in Delhi, if so, why it has not been enhanced; (d) whether a technical survey of the problem areas in the city has been undertaken; and (e) if so, whether a roadmap has been prepared to augment the drainage lines of Delhi-NCR? (a) :  Delhi Police has informed that during the monsoon season, normal flow of traffic in various areas of Delhi is disrupted due to water logging. (b) :  The Government of National Capital Territory of Delhi (GNCTD), who deal with the matter, has informed that the average daily rainfall in Delhi, during the monsoon seasons is around 50 mm/day.  Accordingly, the roads were designed to cater to the requirement of the average rainfall. However, in the recent years, it is seen that heavy and concentrated rainfall over 100 mm/day, is received on a few occasions.  Such heavy rainfall, which is far in excess of the average daily rainfall, creates some problems of water logging in some parts of Delhi.  Consistent efforts are undertaken, to upgrade the road network in the city, which helps in maintenance and the augmentation of drainage capacity. (c) to (e) : Drainage issue of Delhi is dealt with by GNCTD and they have informed that Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) of Delhi has submitted a new Delhi Drainage Master Plan.  After conducting  studies,  the  augmentation  of  drainage  system  will  take  place  as  per  solutions suggested.',

['SHRI PANKAJ CHAUDHRY MINISTER OF STATE FOR FINANCE (a) to (c): Yes. SEBI receives complaints, alleging violations of the SEBI (Prohibition of Insider  Trading)  Regulations,  2015  (PIT  Regulations),  against  insiders,  including  senior officials of companies. Such complaints are treated as inputs for market intelligence and surveillance and dealt with in a confidential manner. Based on the information available and the merits of the case, examination is initiated in cases of prima facie evidence of violations, and wherever necessary, detailed investigation is initiated. In case where any entity is found to have violated securities laws including PIT Regulations, SEBI, after examining the same, takes action as warranted. The orders passed by SEBI are available  in  public  domain  and  can  be  accessed  from  the  SEBI  website  i.e. https://www.sebi.gov.in/.',
 'THE MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF COMMERCE AND INDUSTRY (SMT. ANUPRIYA PATEL) (a) & (b):  Government has taken various initiatives through the individual Commodity Boards to extend support by way of providing financial and technical assistance for various developmental activities viz. Replantation, expansion, water augmentation, quality  upgradation, formation  of Farmer Producer Organization etc. to help the traditional growers towards sustainable coffee cultivation. Coffee is grown as a silvi-horticulture crop in the eco sensitive Western and Eastern ghats under two tier shade canopy such as top canopy of permanent tree cover and lower canopy of fast-growing temporary shade trees. This condition provides suitable micro climate that exist in natural habitats of coffee (Ethiopian tropical rain forest). This unique way of traditional coffee cultivation provides additional advantage of growing intercrops / associate crops like pepper and cardamom in Coffee plantation. 1 In case of tea, the functioning of the tea gardens is mostly on leased land allotted by the respective State Government only for the purpose of tea and its allied activities. (c) & (d): The details of states and districts where provision of financial and technical assistance has been made in the current financial year 2021-22, for the growers in the areas, where pepper and cardamom are grown as inter crops in coffee plantations is at Annexure. Further,  the  Government  through  Spices  Board  has  established  5  numbers  of  departmental nurseries in Karnataka (Belagola, Bettidamane, Yeslur, Aigoor & Beligeri) and 9 development officers to provide assistance to various stakeholders for production of small cardamom and post- harvest improvement of spices, including black pepper. The departmental nurseries, in addition to its primary mandate for production of small cardamom seedlings, are producing and distributing Black pepper rooted cuttings and black pepper nucleus planting materials to spice farmers, stake holders and coffee growers directly  and also through the Coffee Board. Details of Black pepper rooted cuttings distributed from departmental nurseries in Karnataka since 2017-18 are given below: *The supply of planting materials to growers, Coffee Board and Integrated Tribal Development Agency (ITDA), Paderu during 2021-22 is continuing. 2 Annexure 3',
 "MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS (SHRI AJAY KUMAR MISHRA) (a) to (c):  National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) compiles and publishes statistical data on crimes in its publication “Crime in India”. The published reports are available till the year 2020. The details of State/UT-wise Cases Registered (CR) and Conviction Rate (CVR) under Rape (Sec. 376 IPC) for Crime   against   Women   during   the   years   2018-2020  are  available  at  \x0cPage2_pdfplumber --2-- R.S.US.Q.NO. 1634 FOR 16.03.2022 Annexure-I. Further, the details of State/UT-wise number of cases in which offenders were known to the Rape Victims during the years 2018-2020 are available at Annexure-II. (d):  No Such trend is seen as per the data at Annexure-I. (e) to (g):  „Police‟ and „Public Order‟ are State subjects under the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution of India. The responsibilities to maintain law and  order,  protection  of  life  and  property  of  the  citizens  including investigation  and  prosecution  of  crime  against  women  rest  with  the respective State Governments. The State Governments are competent to deal  with  such  offences  under  the  extant  provisions  of  laws.  However, Government  has  taken  the  following  measures  to  ensure  faster adjudication of cases concerning crime against women:- i.  The Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2018 mandates completion of investigation and filing of charge sheet in rape cases in 2 months and trials also to be completed in 2 months (Section 173 Cr.P.C.). ii.  MHA has launched the “National Database on Sexual Offenders” (NDSO)  on  20th  September,  2018  to  facilitate  investigation  and tracking of sexual offenders across the country. iii.  MHA has launched an online analytic tool “Investigation Tracking System for Sexual Offences” to monitor and track time-bound  \x0cPage3_pdfplumber --3-- R.S.US.Q.NO. 1634 FOR 16.03.2022 investigation in sexual assault cases in accordance with Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2018. iv.  In  order  to  improve  investigation,  MHA  has  taken  steps  to strengthen  DNA  analysis  units  in  Central  and  State  Forensic Science Laboratories.  This includes setting up of State-of-the-Art DNA  Analysis  Unit  in  Central  Forensic  Science  Laboratory, Chandigarh. MHA has also sanctioned setting-up and upgrading of DNA Analysis units in State Forensic Science Laboratories in 23 States/UTs. v.  MHA has notified guidelines for collection of forensic evidence in sexual  assault  cases  and  the  standard  composition  in  a  sexual assault evidence collection kit.  To facilitate adequate capacity in manpower,  training  and  skill  building  programs  have  been undertaken  for  Investigation  Officers,  Prosecution  Officers  and Medical Officers.  Bureau of Police Research & Development has distributed  14,950  Sexual  Assault  Evidence  Collection  Kits  to States/ UTs as orientation kit as part of training. vi.  In  addition  to  the  above-mentioned  measures,  MHA  has  been issuing advisories from time to time to States/UTs to deal with crimes against women, which are available at www.mha.gov.in. \x0cPage4_pdfplumber --4-- R.S.US.Q.NO. 1634 FOR 16.03.2022 Further,  Government  of  India  has  initiated  the  process  for comprehensive amendments to criminal laws viz. Indian Penal Code, 1860, the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 and the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 in consultation with all Stakeholders. A  Centrally  Sponsored  Scheme  for  setting  up  of  1023  Fast  Track Special  Courts  (FTSCs)  including  389  exclusive  POCSO  Courts  was launched by the Central Government in the year 2019-20 to provide speedy justice  to  the  victims  of  rape  and  POCSO  Act.  As  on  31.12.2021,  27 States/UTs  have  operationalized  700  FTSCs  including  383  exclusive POCSO Courts.
